DOCNAME: CASE OF GLAS NADEZHDA EOOD AND ANATOLIY ELENKOV v. BULGARIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Not necessary to examine Art. 9;Violation of Art. 13+10;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , is a NORP and a follower of ORG in GPE . In DATE he decided to set up PERSON ORG , through which he would apply for a broadcasting licence for a religious radio station . He obtained support for this initiative from many domestic and foreign religious figures of various denominations , as well as from ORG at ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG announced that a number of frequencies for local radio broadcasting would be made available to private operators in several cities . CARDINAL such licences were available for GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON EOOD applied to ORG ( “ the STC ” – see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) for a broadcasting licence for a radio station with NORP religious programming for GPE . In support of its application it presented , inter alia , a business plan , a programme project , a programme concept , a programme profile , and a programme scheme . It was apparent from these that it intended to broadcast mainly NORP religious programming .

CARDINAL . NORP In line with the established procedure , the application was forwarded to ORG ( “ the ORG ” – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . After deliberating on the application on DATE , the ORG refused in a decision of DATE , which was not notified to PERSON ORG , to grant a broadcasting licence . It stated , without adding further detail , that although the company had submitted all the requisite documents , its programme documents did not correspond to points CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG 's criteria for licensing regional overtheair radio operators , and only partly corresponded to points CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Furthermore , PERSON ORG had no prior experience of creating programmes in the region .
CARDINAL . In accordance with the established procedure ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , this decision was sent to the STC .
CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE the ORG refused to grant a broadcasting licence to PERSON ORG . It stated that its refusal was based on the ORG 's decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . PERSON EOOD lodged an application for judicial review of the ORG 's decision with ORG . It submitted that , since it was not clear whether the ORG 's decision was subject to direct review , the court should first examine its lawfulness before ruling on the lawfulness of the ORG 's decision . PERSON ORG further argued that it had produced all of the requisite documents , each of which corresponded to the ORG 's criteria . The fact that no reasons had been given on how , in the ORG 's view , these documents failed to meet the criteria , was in breach of the rules of procedure and the requirement that administrative decisions be reasoned . On the contrary , all of the ORG 's criteria had been complied with . The decisions had also been in breach of the substantive law and did not correspond to the latter 's object and purpose . In a supplementary memorial PERSON ORG made detailed submissions in respect of each of its alleged failures to comply with the relevant ORG criteria .

CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of DATE , a threemember panel of ORG dismissed the application . It held that the ORG 's decision was subject to review in separate proceedings . However , PERSON ORG had not sought such review , whereas indirect review of that decision in proceedings against the ORG 's decision was impossible . The court went on to say that the ORG 's decision concerned the allocation of the radio spectrum , whereas the ORG 's decision related to the broadcasting content . It was therefore impossible to grant a broadcasting licence without a prior finding by the ORG that it would be used for broadcasting quality programmes . In issuing its decision , the ORG was therefore bound by the ORG 's decision and the latter 's refusal had effectively precluded the former from granting the requested licence .

CARDINAL . PERSON EOOD appealed on points of law to a CARDINAL - member panel of ORG . It argued , inter alia , that while it could be accepted that the ORG 's refusal was binding on the STC , the former was bound to give reasons for its decision .

CARDINAL . In a final judgment of DATE the fivemember panel of ORG upheld the CARDINAL - member panel 's judgment , holding , inter alia , that the STC was bound by the ORG 's decision and could not have reviewed its lawfulness . Nor could the court , in proceedings against the ORG 's decision , examine the lawfulness of the ORG 's decision . It could do so only pursuant to an application for judicial review of the latter 's decision .

CARDINAL . Having been apprised of the tenor of the ORG 's decision in the course of the proceedings for judicial review of the ORG 's decision , on DATE PERSON made an application for its judicial review . It submitted that it had provided all necessary documents , thus establishing that it had complied with the ORG 's licensing criteria . However , that body had not pointed out any perceived deficiencies , thus failing to provide a duly reasoned decision and acting in breach of the rules of administrative procedure .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE a threemember panel of ORG dismissed the application . It held that the ORG 's assessment of whether the licence application met its criteria was not subject to judicial scrutiny , since the ORG enjoyed discretion in that respect . In the instant case it had found that the programme documents submitted by PERSON ORG did not meet its requirements for regional targeting , societal function and business perspective of the programming , and only partially met its criteria regarding the justification and uniqueness of its programme profile , conformity with the audience 's expectations and professional and technological resources . These findings fell within the exclusive province of the ORG .
CARDINAL . PERSON EOOD appealed on points of law to a fivemember panel of ORG , reiterating its arguments .
CARDINAL . In a final judgment of DATE the CARDINAL - member panel of ORG upheld the threemember panel 's judgment , fully endorsing its reasoning .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON , acting on behalf of PERSON ORG , requested the ORG to provide it with a copy of TIME of the deliberations at which it had examined its application for a broadcasting licence . He relied on ORG “ ORG за достъп до обществена информация ” ) .
CARDINAL . As the ORG did not reply within the statutory timelimit , PERSON PERSON asked ORG to review its tacit refusal .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE the ORG quashed the ORG 's tacit refusal and ordered it to reply to the request for information . It held that TIME of the ORG 's deliberations were public information within the meaning of ORG .

CARDINAL . The ORG did not appeal and shortly afterwards the judgment entered into force . However , at the time of the latest receipt of information from the applicants ( DATE ) the ORG had still not complied with the judgment and had not replied to the applicants ' request for information .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW of DATE read as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Freedom of conscience , freedom of thought and choice of religion or of religious or atheistic views shall be inviolable . The ORG shall assist in the maintenance of tolerance and respect between the adherents of different denominations , and between believers and non - believers .
CARDINAL . Freedom of conscience and religion shall not be exercised to the detriment of national security , public order , public health and morals , or of the rights and freedoms of others . ”
“ CARDINAL . Everyone is entitled to express an opinion or to publicise it through words , written or oral , sound , or image , or in any other way .

CARDINAL . NORP This right shall not be used to the detriment of the rights and reputation of others , or for the incitement of a forcible change of the constitutionally established order , the perpetration of a crime , or the incitement of enmity or violence against anyone . ”
“ CARDINAL . The press and the other mass media shall be free and not subject to censorship .

CARDINAL . Printed matter or another information medium may be stopped or confiscated only pursuant to an act of the judicial authorities , where it encroaches on good morals or incites to a forcible change of the constitutionally established order , the perpetration of a crime or an act of violence against the person . ... ”

“ CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to seek , receive and impart information . The exercise of that right may not be directed against the rights and the good name of other citizens , nor against national security , public order , public health or morals .

CARDINAL . NORP Citizens shall have the right to information from state bodies or agencies on any matter of legitimate interest to them , unless the information is a state secret or a secret protected by law , or it affects the rights of others . ”

CARDINAL . At the material time LAW DATE ( “ ORG за далекосъобщенията ” ) regulated all forms of telecommunication , such as telephony and radio and television broadcasting . The main regulatory body having authority under the LAW was the STC ( renamed ORG in DATE ) . At the relevant time it had the power to , inter alia , grant , amend , supplement , freeze , discontinue and withdraw radio and television broadcasting licences , following a decision by the ORG ( section CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the material time ) .

CARDINAL . The STC was a collective body attached to ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the material time ) . It had CARDINAL members , nominated by ORG and appointed by the prime minister for a term of DATE , renewable once ( section PERSON ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the material time ) . The members could be dismissed prematurely only if they resigned , seriously breached the provisions of the LAW , seriously or systematically violated their official duties , committed a wilful publicly prosecutable criminal offence , or were unable to perform their duties for DATE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the material time ) . The organisation and the operation of the STC and of its secretariat were laid down in regulations issued by ORG ( section CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the material time ) .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) of ORG DATE ( “ ORG за радиото и телевизията ” ) , as in force at the relevant time , radio and television broadcasting was only allowed under a licence granted by the ORG . The application for a licence had to be filed with the STC and accompanied by , as relevant , a programme project , a programme concept , a programme profile and a programme scheme ( section CARDINAL of the Act , as in force at the relevant time ) . A STC official checked the submitted documents and , if he or she found any irregularities , advised the applicant , which then had DATE to rectify them . If the applicant failed to do so , the application was not considered ( section CARDINAL of the LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) . The STC was to transmit the accepted application , plus enclosures , to the ORG ( section CARDINAL of the Act , as in force at the relevant time ) , which then had to make a reasoned decision on the application within DATE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) . The decision was then transmitted to the STC within DATE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) , which issued the licence , where appropriate , within DATE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG was an independent body responsible for protecting freedom of expression , the independence of radio and television operators and the interests of the audience ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) . CARDINAL of its CARDINAL members were elected by ORG , and the remaining CARDINAL were appointed by the President of the Republic ( section CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) . CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG gave judgment ( реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL юни DATE г. по PERSON № DATE г. , обн. GPE , бр. CARDINAL от CARDINAL юли DATE г. ) in proceedings brought by CARDINAL members of ORG who considered that a number of provisions of ORG DATE should be declared contrary to LAW . The court held , as relevant :

“ Under LAW [ DATE ] , licences are granted by the ORG and approved by ORG . Whereas this licensing relates to the setting up of telecommunication networks and to the use of the radio frequency spectrum and its allocation , the ORG 's decision under the [ Radio and Television Act DATE ] relates to the content of the services which will be broadcast . The provisions of the [ Telecommunications Act DATE ] relate to licensing for the setting up of telecommunications networks and the provision of services through the radio frequency spectrum . Supervision of the preparation , creation and broadcasting of radio and television programmes ... falls outside the competence of the STC .

As regards the media , and radio and television in particular , there exists the instruction [ implicit ] in LAW that they be transformed into autonomous public institutions , freed of the tutelage of a specific government agency . For this reason the regulation of radio and television is entrusted ... to the ORG , which is not a government agency .

Over DATE NORP law has for the first time differentiated between the regimes for establishing telecommunications operators and those for establishing radio and television operators . The licensing of telecommunication operators is governed by the [ Telecommunications Act DATE ] , whereas the licensing in respect of programme content is governed by the [ LAW DATE ] . These are CARDINAL differing types of activity : the first mainly monitors compliance with technological requirements under the [ Telecommunications Act DATE ] , whereas the second monitors aesthetical and artistic qualities under the [ LAW DATE ] . At the same time , the media law does not allow the independence of the procedure for issuing radio and television licences to be called into question , because section CARDINAL of the [ LAW DATE ] instructs the ORG to make a reasoned decision on each application for a licence for electronic media broadcasting . If the ORG 's decision is to allow the application , it encloses the draft licence . The assertion ... that ' the STC is not bound by the decision of the ORG [ and that ORG may grant a licence or deny CARDINAL irrespective of the positive decision of the ORG ' is unfounded . The [ STC ] has no right to review compliance with the criteria laid down in the [ LAW DATE ] . All questions relating to the granting , modification , or withdrawal of radio and television broadcasting licences , respectively to guaranteeing freedom of expression through the media , fall within the mandate of the ORG .

This court has many times ruled on the relations between the communications rights and the regulatory bodies in the information field . The connection between freedom of speech and the powers of the STC were examined in judgment no . DATE [ ( решение № CARDINAL от CARDINAL декември DATE г. по PERSON № CARDINAL от DATE г. , обн. , DATE , брой CARDINAL от CARDINAL декември DATE г. ) ] , whose reasoning is also applicable in the instant case . This judgment states : ' As already found by [ this court ] in its judgment no . DATE [ ( решение № CARDINAL от DATE г. по PERSON № DATE г. , обн. , ДВ , брой CARDINAL от CARDINAL юни DATE г. ) ] , ORG interference in the allocation of the radio frequency spectrum is inevitable . It follows that the freedom of the electronic media under LAW does not exclude ORG interference . The underlying principles of LAW may be complied with by making the licensing conditions and procedure public , accessible and preordained . ' ”
CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Telecommunications Act DATE , the decisions of the STC were subject to review by ORG .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of ORG DATE , as worded at the material time , provided that the ORG 's decisions to grant , amend or withdraw a broadcasting licence were also subject to review by ORG .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ( “ ORG за административното производство ” ) , which at the material time regulated , inter alia , the procedure for judicial review of administrative decisions , the reviewing court had to verify whether an administrative decision was lawful , that is , made by a competent body in due form , in compliance with the relevant procedural and substantive rules , and in conformity with the object and purpose of the law . Similarly , section CARDINAL of ORG ( “ ORG за Върховния административен съд ” ) , as in force at the relevant time , provided that the grounds for annulling administrative decisions were lack of competence of the body which had made the decision , its failure to make the decision in due form , a material breach of the rules of administrative procedure , a breach of the substantive law or nonconformity with the object and purpose of the law .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG Recommendation no . R ( CARDINAL ) CARDINAL to Member GPE on the independence and functions of regulatory authorities for the broadcasting sector , in which it recommended that the Member GPE , inter alia , “ include provisions in their legislation and measures in their policies entrusting the regulatory authorities for the broadcasting sector with powers which enable them to fulfil their missions , as prescribed by national law , in an effective , independent and transparent manner , in accordance with the guidelines set out in the appendix to this recommendation ” .
CARDINAL . The guidelines , featuring as an appendix to the recommendation , provide , as relevant :

CARDINAL . The rules governing regulatory authorities for the broadcasting sector , especially their membership , are a key element of their independence . Therefore , they should be defined so as to protect them against any interference , in particular by political forces or economic interests .
CARDINAL . For this purpose , specific rules should be defined as regards incompatibilities in order to avoid that :
– regulatory authorities are under the influence of political power ;

– members of regulatory authorities exercise functions or hold interests in enterprises or other organisations in the media or related sectors , which might lead to a conflict of interest in connection with membership of the regulatory authority .
CARDINAL . Furthermore , rules should guarantee that the members of these authorities :
– are appointed in a democratic and transparent manner ;
– may not receive any mandate or take any instructions from any person or body ;
– do not make any statement or undertake any action which may prejudice the independence of their functions and do not take any advantage of them .

CARDINAL . One of the essential tasks of regulatory authorities in the broadcasting sector is normally the granting of broadcasting licences . The basic conditions and criteria governing the granting and renewal of broadcasting licences should be clearly defined in the law .

CARDINAL . The regulations governing the broadcasting licensing procedure should be clear and precise and should be applied in an open , transparent and impartial manner . The decisions made by the regulatory authorities in this context should be subject to adequate publicity .
CARDINAL . All decisions taken and regulations adopted by the regulatory authorities should be :
– duly reasoned , in accordance with national law ;
– open to review by the competent jurisdictions according to national law ;
– made available to the public . ”
